column4: okay well here's _MY_ question, hehe:  I've installed herd4 of feisty successfully... what I would like to know, though, is if changing packages installed while using the livecd has any effect on the packages installed using ubiquity
nope
is there an equivalent of "priority=medium" in ubiquity?
ubiquity just copies the image to the disk
Installation is the same for both, this is a fine channel.
so I'm guessing that the minimal install is a little larger heh
eh? what?
(than usual)
why would minimal be larger?
nevermind I phrased the question wrong... I was basically thinking that there was a smaller minimal installation available.  Anyway, is feisty also going to support the debian-installer or not?
Of course.  Alternate CD has the debian installer (with packages), minimal CD is debian installer (without packages)
nice :D thanks
they'll both download updated packages from the interblags during install though.
I just don't like the whole "pre-configured feel" of ubiquity for some reason, even tho I think it will be great for entry-level
I'm a straight debian user if you take 'most time spent' into account
so I'm all about as many options as I can get hehe even if I leave them at default

yeah, well, most people who want to just install prefer the alt CD anyway, not having to boot first, etc.  Alt/Minimal CD have a few install options (full desktop, CLI only), but I don't believe ubiquity is less optionful (except in LVM, etc), assuming you're doing a full desktop install

okay.  Never have done an Ubuntu install, but I was looking at ways to "complicate" (I guess would be the word) the install, and debian-installer run with the "priority=low" or "medium" boot options looked promising for more customization
I suppose you can enable "expert" mode on alternate CD.  But really, there's... not really any benefit to doing so.  You'll just defer your OS installation
gotcha... good to know
any config you can do there, would probably be better served after installation (well, unless you need to specify hardware parameters to get it to work)
actually feisty detected everything perfectly on a somewhat-new laptop (Sony VAIO VGN-N130G) -- even found the drivers for the control device and other sony-specifics)
right. They're pretty good at doing that
